segment.source: DCOM Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax (Windows 10)
segment.target: DCOM Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the DCOM Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the DCOM Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax policy setting.

segment.source: DCOM: Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax
segment.target: DCOM: Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the DCOM: Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the DCOM: Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax policy setting.

segment.source: Reference
segment.target: Reference

segment.source: This policy setting allows you to define additional computer-wide controls that govern access to all Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM)–based applications on a device.
segment.target: This policy setting allows you to define additional computer-wide controls that govern access to all Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM)–based applications on a device.

segment.source: These controls restrict call, activation, or launch requests on the device.
segment.target: These controls restrict call, activation, or launch requests on the device.

segment.source: A simple way to think about these access controls is as an additional access check that is performed against a device-wide access control list (ACL) on each call, activation, or launch of any COM-based server.
segment.target: A simple way to think about these access controls is as an additional access check that is performed against a device-wide access control list (ACL) on each call, activation, or launch of any COM-based server.

segment.source: If the access check fails, the call, activation, or launch request is denied.
segment.target: If the access check fails, the call, activation, or launch request is denied.

segment.source: (This check is in addition to any access check that is run against the server-specific ACLs.) In effect, it provides a minimum authorization standard that must be passed to access any COM-based server.
segment.target: (This check is in addition to any access check that is run against the server-specific ACLs.) In effect, it provides a minimum authorization standard that must be passed to access any COM-based server.

segment.source: This policy setting controls access permissions to cover call rights.
segment.target: This policy setting controls access permissions to cover call rights.

segment.source: These device-wide ACLs provide a way to override weak security settings that are specified by an application through the CoInitializeSecurity function or application-specific security settings.
segment.target: These device-wide ACLs provide a way to override weak security settings that are specified by an application through the CoInitializeSecurity function or application-specific security settings.

segment.source: They provide a minimum security standard that must be passed, regardless of the settings of the specific server.
segment.target: They provide a minimum security standard that must be passed, regardless of the settings of the specific server.

segment.source: These ACLs also provide a centralized location for an administrator to set a general authorization policy that applies to all COM-based servers on the device.
segment.target: These ACLs also provide a centralized location for an administrator to set a general authorization policy that applies to all COM-based servers on the device.

segment.source: This policy setting allows you to specify an ACL in two different ways.
segment.target: This policy setting allows you to specify an ACL in two different ways.

segment.source: You can type the security descriptor in SDDL, or you can grant or deny Local Access and Remote Access permissions to users and groups.
segment.target: You can type the security descriptor in SDDL, or you can grant or deny Local Access and Remote Access permissions to users and groups.

segment.source: We recommend that you use the built-in user interface to specify the ACL contents that you want to apply with this setting.
segment.target: We recommend that you use the built-in user interface to specify the ACL contents that you want to apply with this setting.

segment.source: The default ACL settings vary, depending on the version of Windows you are running.
segment.target: The default ACL settings vary, depending on the version of Windows you are running.

segment.source: Possible values
segment.target: Possible values

segment.source: User-defined input of the SDDL representation of the groups and privileges
segment.target: User-defined input of the SDDL representation of the groups and privileges

segment.source: When you specify the users or groups that are to be given permissions, the security descriptor field is populated with the Security Descriptor Definition Language representation of those groups and privileges.
segment.target: When you specify the users or groups that are to be given permissions, the security descriptor field is populated with the Security Descriptor Definition Language representation of those groups and privileges.

segment.source: Users and groups can be given explicit Allow or Deny privileges for local access and remote access.
segment.target: Users and groups can be given explicit Allow or Deny privileges for local access and remote access.

segment.source: Blank
segment.target: Blank

segment.source: This represents how the local security policy deletes the policy enforcement key.
segment.target: This represents how the local security policy deletes the policy enforcement key.

segment.source: This value deletes the policy and then sets it as Not defined.
segment.target: This value deletes the policy and then sets it as Not defined.

segment.source: The Blank value is set by using the ACL editor to empty the list, and then pressing OK.
segment.target: The Blank value is set by using the ACL editor to empty the list, and then pressing OK.

segment.source: Location
segment.target: Location

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.target: Default values

segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.target: Server type or GPO

segment.source: Policy management
segment.target: Policy management

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Restart requirement
segment.target: Restart requirement

segment.source: None.
segment.target: None.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a computer restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a computer restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Group Policy
segment.target: Group Policy

segment.source: The registry settings that are created as a result of enabling the DCOM: Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax policy setting take precedence over the previous registry settings when this policy setting was configured.
segment.target: The registry settings that are created as a result of enabling the DCOM: Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax policy setting take precedence over the previous registry settings when this policy setting was configured.

segment.source: The Remote Procedure Call (RPC) service checks the new registry keys in the Policies section for the computer restrictions, and these registry entries take precedence over the existing registry keys under OLE.
segment.target: The Remote Procedure Call (RPC) service checks the new registry keys in the Policies section for the computer restrictions, and these registry entries take precedence over the existing registry keys under OLE.

segment.source: This means that previously existing registry settings are no longer effective, and if you make changes to the existing settings, device access permissions for users are not changed.
segment.target: This means that previously existing registry settings are no longer effective, and if you make changes to the existing settings, device access permissions for users are not changed.

segment.source: Use care in configuring the list of users and groups.
segment.target: Use care in configuring the list of users and groups.

segment.source: If the administrator is denied permission to access DCOM applications due to the changes made to DCOM in the Windows operating system, the administrator can use the DCOM: Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax policy setting to manage DCOM access to the computer.
segment.target: If the administrator is denied permission to access DCOM applications due to the changes made to DCOM in the Windows operating system, the administrator can use the DCOM: Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax policy setting to manage DCOM access to the computer.

segment.source: The administrator can use this setting to specify which users and groups can access the DCOM application on the computer locally and remotely.
segment.target: The administrator can use this setting to specify which users and groups can access the DCOM application on the computer locally and remotely.

segment.source: This will restore control of the DCOM application to the administrator and users.
segment.target: This will restore control of the DCOM application to the administrator and users.

segment.source: To do this, open the DCOM: Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax setting, and click Edit Security.
segment.target: To do this, open the DCOM: Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax setting, and click Edit Security.

segment.source: Specify the users or groups you want to include and the computer access permissions for those users or groups.
segment.target: Specify the users or groups you want to include and the computer access permissions for those users or groups.

segment.source: This defines the setting and sets the appropriate SDDL value.
segment.target: This defines the setting and sets the appropriate SDDL value.

segment.source: Security considerations
segment.target: Security considerations

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Vulnerability
segment.target: Vulnerability

segment.source: Many COM applications include some security-specific code (for example, to call CoInitializeSecurity), but they use weak settings that allow unauthenticated access to the process.
segment.target: Many COM applications include some security-specific code (for example, to call CoInitializeSecurity), but they use weak settings that allow unauthenticated access to the process.

segment.source: Administrators cannot override these settings to force stronger security in earlier versions of Windows without modifying the application.
segment.target: Administrators cannot override these settings to force stronger security in earlier versions of Windows without modifying the application.

segment.source: An attacker could attempt to exploit weak security in an individual application by attacking it through COM calls.
segment.target: An attacker could attempt to exploit weak security in an individual application by attacking it through COM calls.

segment.source: Also, the COM infrastructure includes the Remote Procedure Call Services (RPCSS), a system service that runs during and after computer startup.
segment.target: Also, the COM infrastructure includes the Remote Procedure Call Services (RPCSS), a system service that runs during and after computer startup.

segment.source: This service manages activation of COM objects and the running object table and provides helper services to DCOM remoting.
segment.target: This service manages activation of COM objects and the running object table and provides helper services to DCOM remoting.

segment.source: It exposes RPC interfaces that can be called remotely.
segment.target: It exposes RPC interfaces that can be called remotely.

segment.source: Because some COM-based servers allow unauthenticated remote access, these interfaces can be called by anyone, including unauthenticated users.
segment.target: Because some COM-based servers allow unauthenticated remote access, these interfaces can be called by anyone, including unauthenticated users.

segment.source: As a result, RPCSS can be attacked by malicious users who use remote, unauthenticated computers.
segment.target: As a result, RPCSS can be attacked by malicious users who use remote, unauthenticated computers.

segment.source: Countermeasure
segment.target: Countermeasure

segment.source: To protect individual COM-based applications or services, set the DCOM: Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax setting to an appropriate device-wide ACL.
segment.target: To protect individual COM-based applications or services, set the DCOM: Machine Access Restrictions in Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) syntax setting to an appropriate device-wide ACL.

segment.source: Potential impact
segment.target: Potential impact

segment.source: Windows implements default COM ACLs when they are installed.
segment.target: Windows implements default COM ACLs when they are installed.

segment.source: Modifying these ACLs from the default may cause some applications or components that communicate by using DCOM to fail.
segment.target: Modifying these ACLs from the default may cause some applications or components that communicate by using DCOM to fail.

segment.source: If you implement a COM-based server and you override the default security settings, confirm that the application-specific call permissions that ACL assigns are the correct permissions for appropriate users.
segment.target: If you implement a COM-based server and you override the default security settings, confirm that the application-specific call permissions that ACL assigns are the correct permissions for appropriate users.

segment.source: If it does not, you must change your application-specific permission ACL to provide appropriate users with activation rights so that applications and Windows components that use DCOM do not fail.
segment.target: If it does not, you must change your application-specific permission ACL to provide appropriate users with activation rights so that applications and Windows components that use DCOM do not fail.

segment.target: Related topics
